Kamal Ahmed wrote:

> Any idea, Anyone on how to go about testing this? Because, When I am trying
> to use the TimePeriod constructor, I get an error:
> 
> "Change the visibility of TimePeriod.java to public.

I don't know how to help you here.

If you don't understand the error message, then please ask a coworker 
about private, protected and public keywords in Java. This is the wrong 
forum to ask fundamental Java questions. You can also find online 
tutorials on Java. Search with google.com.

If you can't change the visibility of TimePeriod (because you don't own 
the class), then there are a few options:

1. Is there another way to create TimePeriod objects? A creation method 
instead of the constructor, for example.

2. Can you ask the class owner to make the constructor public?

If #1 and #2 do not help, then search with google.com for "JUnit test 
private methods". The advice there also applies to protected methods.
